'''Obscurantism''' ({{lang-fr|obscurantisme}}, from the Latin ''obscurans'', âdarkeningâ) is the practice of deliberately preventing the facts or the full details of some matter from becoming known. There are two, common, historical and intellectual, denotations: 1) restricting knowledgeâopposition to the spread of [[knowledge]], a policy of withholding knowledge from the [[public]], and, 2) deliberate obscurityâan abstruse style (as in [[literature]] and [[art]]) characterized by deliberate vagueness.<ref>[http://www.m-w.com/dictionary/obscurantism Merriam-Webster Online, "Obscurantism"], retrieved on 4 August 2007.</ref><ref>''Websterâs New Universal Unabridged Dictionary'' (1996) p. 1337</ref>
[[Image:Johannes Reuchlin.JPG|thumb|right|150px|'''Anti-obscurantist:''' [[Johann Reuchlin]] (1455â1522).]]
The term ''obscurantism'' derives from the title of the 16th-century satire ''[[EpistolÃ¦ Obscurorum Virorum]]'' (''Letters of Obscure Men''), based upon the [[intellectual]] dispute between the German humanist [[Johann Reuchlin]] and [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] monks, such as [[Johannes Pfefferkorn]], about whether or not all [[Judaism|Jewish]] books should be [[Book burning|burned]] as un-Christian. Earlier, in 1509, the monk Pfefferkorn had obtained permission from [[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian I]] (1486â1519), the Holy Roman Emperor, to incinerate all copies of the [[Talmud]] ([[Jewish law]] and [[Jewish ethics]]) known to be in the [[Holy Roman Empire]]; the ''Letters of Obscure Men'' satirized the Dominican monks' arguments for burning âun-Christianâ works.
In the 18th century, [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] philosophers used the term "obscurantism" to denote the enemies of the Enlightenment and its concept of the liberal diffusion of knowledge. Moreover, in the 19th century, in distinguishing the varieties of obscurantism found in [[metaphysics]] and [[theology]] from the âmore subtleâ obscurantism of [[Immanuel Kant]]'s [[critical philosophy]], and of modern [[philosophical skepticism]], [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] said: âThe essential element in the black art of obscurantism is not that it wants to darken individual understanding, but that it wants to blacken our picture of the world, and darken our idea of existence.â<ref>Nietzsche, F. (1878) ''[[Human, All Too Human]]'' Vol. II, Part 1, 27. Cambridge University Press; 2 edition (November 13, 1996). ISBN 978-0-521-56704-6</ref>
==Restricting knowledge== [[Image:Marquis de condorcet hd.jpg||thumb|upright|120px|[[Marquis de Condorcet]]]]
[[Image:H l mencken.jpg|thumb|left|120px|[[H. L. Mencken]]]]
In restricting knowledge to an [[Elite|Ã©lite]] ruling class of âthe fewâ, obscurantism is fundamentally [[democracy|anti-democratic]], because its component [[anti-intellectualism]] and [[elitism]] exclude the people as [[intellect]]ually unworthy of knowing the facts and truth about the [[government]] of their [[City-State]].<ref name=Hersh>[[Seymour Hersh|Seymour M. Hersh]], [http://www.newyorker.com/fact/content/?030512fa_fact "Selective Intelligence"], ''[[The New Yorker]]'', 12 May 2003, accessed June 1, 2007.</ref><ref name="reason">Brian Doherty, [http://www.reason.com/9707/fe.bailey.shtml "Origin of the Specious: Why Do Neoconservatives Doubt Darwin?"], ''[[Reason Online]]'' July 1997, accessed 16 February 2007.</ref> In 18th-century monarchic France, the [[Marquis de Condorcet]], as a [[political science|political scientist]], documented the [[aristocracy]]âs obscurantism about the social problems that provoked the [[French Revolution]] (1789â99) that deposed them and their [[List of French monarchs|King]], [[Louis XVI of France]].
In the 19th century, the [[mathematics|mathematician]] [[William Kingdon Clifford]], an early proponent of [[Darwinism]], devoted some writings to uprooting obscurantism in England, after hearing clerics â who privately agreed with him about evolution â publicly denounce [[evolution]] as unâ[[Christianity|Christian]]. Moreover, in the realm of organized religion, obscurantism usually is associated with religious [[fundamentalism]], but is a distinct strain of thought independent of theologic allegiance. The distinction is that fundamentalism presupposes sincere religious belief, whereas obscurantism is based upon minority manipulation of the popular faith as political praxis, (cf. [[Censorship]]).<ref name = Obs>Syed, I. (2002) [http://www.irfi.org/articles/articles_51_100/obscurantism.htm "Obscurantism"]. From: ''Intellectual Achievements of Muslims''. New Delhi: Star Publications. Excerpt available online. Retrieved on: 4 August 2007.</ref>
The obscurantist can be personally a [[scientist]],a [[philosopher]], a truly [[Faith|faithful]] person, a [[atheism|naturalist]], or just [[agnosticism|agnostic]], but, as one member of the society, believes that religion among the populace serves the aim of social control. To that effect, the obscurant limits the publication, extension, and dissemination of knowledge, of evidence countering the common-belief ''status quo'' with which the nation are ruled â the local variety of the necessary [[Noble Lie]], introduced to political discourse by the [[Classical Greece|Classical Greek]] philosopher [[Plato]] in 380 BC. Hence the âstable-''status quo'' restriction of knowledgeâ denotation of ''obscurantism'' applied by pro-science reformers within religious movements,<ref name = Obs/> and by contemporary [[skeptics]], such as [[H.L. Mencken]], in critiquing [[religion]].<ref>Mencken, H.L. (2002). ''H.L. Mencken on Religion''. Prometheus Books. ISBN 978-1573929820</ref>
===Plato=== [[Image:Plato Silanion Musei Capitolini MC1377.jpg|thumb|right|100px|[[Plato]] (Silanion Musei Capitolini)]]
The obscurant favors restricting knowledge (publication, extension, dissemination) among the populace, for the âgreater goodâ of the nation and the [[City-State]]. [[Classical Greece]] (6â4 c. BC) provides an original and powerful source of obscurantism in ''[[The Republic (Plato)|The Republic]]'' (ca. 380 BC), wherein [[Plato]] proposes government via the [[Noble Lie]] â the necessary mythical justification for the ''status quo'' that guides the [[philosopher king]] in ruling society. To maintaining political stability, the Noble Lie naturally classifies people, determining their places in life and society, per the proportions of gold, silver, and iron, that each man and woman contained when formed in the earth; those meant to [[government|rule]] contained gold, whilst those meant to serve (soldiers, farmers, craftsmen ''et al.'') respectively contained silver and iron.<ref>''The Oxford Guide to Philosophy'' (2005) p. 660</ref>
It is noteworthy that ''PoliteÃ­a'' (âCity-State Governanceâ), i.e. "governing," not "government," is the original title of ''The Republic.'' From this philosophic source then derived [[Neo-Platonism]], [[Christian mysticism]], [[negative theology]], and [[hermeticism]], philosophies which use linguistic and [[logic]]al strategies that indirectly speak about the [[ineffable]] â a concept inexpressible as thought, and only expressible as emotion. Historically, the idea that rulers and leaders know best is inherent to every form of [[totalitarianism]]. In the ''Skeptical Inquirer'' magazine (SeptemberâOctober 2004), the article âObscurantism, Tyranny, and the Fallacy of Either Black or Whiteâ quotes Prof. [[Bergen Evans]]: âObscurantism and tyranny go together.â<ref>{{cite journal | last = Estling | first = Ralph | title = Obscurantism, tyranny, and the fallacy of either black or white | journal = Skeptical Inquirer | date = SeptemberâOctober, 2004 | url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2843/is_5_28/ai_n6361536 | accessdate = 2007-08-18 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071211113456/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2843/is_5_28/ai_n6361536 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-12-11}}</ref>
===Leo Strauss=== ====Political philosophy==== In the 20th century, the American conservative [[political philosophy|political philosopher]] [[Leo Strauss]], for whom philosophy and politics intertwined, and his [[Neoconservatism|Neo-conservative]] adherents adopted the notion of government by the enlightened few as political strategy. He noted that [[intellectuals]], dating from [[Plato]], confronted the dilemma of either an informed populace âinterferingâ with government, or if it were possible for [[Value (ethics)|good]] politicians to be truthful and still govern to maintain a stable society â hence the Noble Lie necessary in securing public acquiescence. In ''The City and Man'' (1964), he discusses the myths in ''[[The Republic (Plato)|The Republic]]'' that Plato proposes effective governing requires, among them, the belief that the country (land) ruled by the State belongs to it (despite some having been conquered from others), and that citizenship derives from more than the [[accident of birth]] in the City-State. Thus, in the ''New Yorker'' magazine article ''Selective Intelligence'', [[Seymour Hersh]] observes that Strauss endorsed the âNoble Lieâ concept: the myths politicians use in maintaining a cohesive society.<ref name="Hersh" /><ref name="reason" />
Prof. [[Shadia Drury]] criticized Straussâs acceptance of dissembling and deception of the populace as âthe peculiar justice of the wiseâ, whereas Plato proposed the Noble Lie as based upon [[Morality|moral]] good. In criticizing ''Natural Right and History'' (1953), she said that âStrauss thinks that the superiority of the ruling philosophers is an intellectual superiority and not a moral one . . . [he] is the only interpreter who gives a sinister reading to Plato, and then celebrates him.â<ref>[http://www.opendemocracy.net/faith-iraqwarphiloshophy/article_1542.jsp Noble lies and perpetual war: Leo Strauss, the neocons, and Iraq openDemocracy<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
====Esoteric texts==== Leo Strauss also was criticized for proposing the notion of "esoteric" meanings to ancient texts, recondite knowledge inaccessible to the âordinaryâ intellect. In ''Persecution and the Art of Writing'' (1952), he proposes that some philosophers write esoterically to avert persecution by the political or religious authorities, and, per his knowledge of [[Maimonides]], [[Al Farabi]], and [[Plato]], proposed that an esoteric writing style is proper for the philosophic text. Rather than explicitly presenting his thoughts, the philosopherâs esoteric writing compels the reader to think independently of the text, and so learn. In the ''[[Phaedrus (Plato)|PhÃ¦drus]]'', Socrates notes that writing does not reply to questions, but invites dialogue with the reader, thereby minimizing the problems of grasping the written word. Strauss noted that one of writingâs political dangers is students' too-readily accepting dangerous ideas â as in the trial of [[Socrates]], wherein the relationship with [[Alcibiades]] was used to prosecute him.
For Leo Strauss, philosophersâ texts offered the reader lucid âexotericâ (salutary) and obscure âesotericâ (true) teachings, which are concealed to the reader of ordinary intellect; emphasizing that writers often left contradictions and other errors to encourage the readerâs more scrupulous (re-)reading of the text. In observing and maintaining the âexoteric â esotericâ dichotomy, Strauss was accused of obscurantism, and for writing esoterically.
===Bill Joy=== In the ''Wired'' magazine article, â[[Why the Future Doesn't Need Us]]â (April 2000), the computer scientist [[Bill Joy]], then a [[Sun Microsystems]] chief scientist, in the sub-title proposed that: âOur most powerful twenty-first-century technologies â robotics, genetic engineering, and nanotech[nology] â are threatening to make humans an endangered speciesâ; in the body, he posits that:
[[Image:Bill joy.jpg|thumb|right|125px|[[Bill Joy]]]]
:The experiences of the [[atomic physics|atomic scientists]] clearly show the need to take personal responsibility, the danger that things will move too fast, and the way in which a process can take on a life of its own. We can, as they did, create insurmountable problems in almost no time flat. We must do more thinking up front if we are not to be similarly surprised and shocked by the consequences of our inventions.â <ref>Khushf, George (2004). âThe Ethics of Nanotechnology: Vision and Values for a New Generation of Science and Engineeringâ, ''Emerging Technologies and Ethical Issues in Engineering'', National Academy of Engineering, pp. 31â32. Washington, DC: The National Academies Press. ISBN 0-309-09271-X.</ref>
Joyâs proposal for limiting the dissemination of âcertainâ knowledge, in behalf of preserving society, was quickly likened to obscurantism. A year later, the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]], in the ''Science and Technology Policy Yearbook 2001'', published the article âA Response to Bill Joy and the Doom-and-Gloom Technofuturistsâ, wherein the computer scientists John Seeley Brown and Paul Duguid countered his proposal as technological tunnel vision, and the predicted, technologically-derived problems as infeasible, for disregarding the influence of non-scientists upon such societal problems.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aaas.org/spp/rd/ch4.pdf |title=A Response to Bill Joy and the Doom-and- Gloom Technofuturists}}</ref>
==Deliberate obscurity== In the second sense, âobscurantismâ denotes making knowledge abstrusely difficult to grasp.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} In the 19th and 20th centuries "obscurantism" became a [[polemics|polemical]] term for accusing an author of deliberately writing obscurely, to hide his or her [[intellectual]] vacuousness. Philosophers who are neither [[empiricism|empiricists]] nor [[positivism|positivists]] often are accused of obscurantism in describing the abstract concepts of their disciplines. For philosophic reasons, these authors might modify, or reject, verifiability, falsifiability, or logical non-contradiction. From said perspective, obscure (clouded, vague, abstruse) writing does not necessarily signal that the writer has a poor grasp of the subject, because unintelligible writing sometimes is purposeful and philosophically considered.<ref name=Rorty>Rorty, Richard (1989) ''Contingency, Irony, and Solidarity''. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, Ch. 6: "From ironist theory to private allusions: Derrida." ISBN 0-521-36781-6.</ref>{{Better source|date=April 2011}}
[[Image:Aristotle Altemps Inv8575.jpg|thumb|right|120px|<center>[[Aristotle]]</center>]]
===Aristotle=== In contemporary discussions of [[virtue ethics]], [[Aristotle]]âs ''[[Nicomachean Ethics]]'' (''The Ethics'') stand accused of ethical obscurantism, because of the technical, philosophic language and writing style, and their purpose being the [[education]] of a cultured governing [[elite|Ã©lite]].<ref name=b>Lisa van Alstyne, "Aristotle's Alleged Ethical Obscurantism." ''Philosophy,'' Vol. 73, No. 285 (Jul., 1998), pp. 429-452.</ref>
===Kant=== Kant employed technical terms that were not commonly understood. Schopenhauer contended that post-Kantian philosophers such as [[Johann Gottlieb Fichte|Fichte]], [[Friedrich Wilhelm Joseph Schelling|Schelling]], and [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel|Hegel]] deliberately mimicked Kant's way of writing. "Because of his style which was obscure, Kant was properly understood by exceedingly few. And it is as if all the philosophical writers, who since Kant had had some success, had devoted themselves to writing still more unintelligibly than Kant. This was bound to succeed!"<ref>Schopenhauer, ''Manuscript Remains'', Vol. 4, "Cogitata I," Â§ 107.</ref>
===According to analytic philosophers=== {{Unbalanced|date=April 2011}} ====Hegel==== [[Image:Hegel.jpg|thumb|left|120px|<center>[[G. W. F. Hegel]]</center>]]
[[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel|G. W. F. Hegel]]'s philosophy, and the philosophies of those he influenced, especially [[Karl Marx]], have been accused of obscurantism. [[Analytic philosophy|Analytic]] and [[Logical positivism|positivistic]] philosophers, such as [[A. J. Ayer]], [[Bertrand Russell]], and the [[Critical Rationalism|critical-rationalist]] [[Karl Popper]], accused Hegel and [[Hegelianism]] of being obscure. About Hegelâs philosophy, [[Arthur Schopenhauer]] wrote that it is: ". . . a colossal piece of mystification, which will yet provide posterity with an inexhaustible theme for laughter at our times, that it is a pseudo-philosophy paralyzing all mental powers, stifling all real thinking, and, by the most outrageous misuse of language, putting in its place the hollowest, most senseless, thoughtless, and, as is confirmed by its success, most stupefying verbiage. . . ."<ref>Schopenhauer, Arthur (1965). ''On the Basis of Morality'', trans. E.F.J.Payne. Indianapolis: Bobbs-Merrill, pp.15-16.</ref>
Nevertheless, biographer Terry Pinkard notes "Hegel has refused to go away, even in analytic philosophy, itself."<ref>''Hegel: A Biography'', Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000, xii.</ref> Hegel was aware of his obscurantism, and perceived it as part of philosophical thinking â to accept and transcend the limitations of quotidian thought and its concepts. In the essay "Who Thinks Abstractly?", he said that it is not the philosopher who thinks abstractly, but the layman, who uses concepts as [[:wikt:given|given]]s that are immutable, without context. It is the philosopher who thinks concretely, because he transcends the limits of quotidian [[concept]]s, in order to understand their broader context. This makes philosophical thought and language appear obscure, esoteric, and mysterious to the layman.
====Marx and Marxism==== [[Image:Marx4.jpg|thumb|120px|right|<center>[[Karl Marx]] in 1861</center>]]
In his early works,<ref>See his ''[[The German Ideology]]'' (1844), ''[[The Poverty of Philosophy]]'' (1845), and ''[[The Holy Family (book)|The Holy Family]]'' (1847).</ref> [[Karl Marx]] criticized German and French philosophy, especially [[German Idealism]], for their traditions of German irrationalism and ideologically motivated obscurantism.<ref>See, Dallmayr, Fred R., "The Discourse of Modernity: Hegel, Nietzsche, Heidegger (and Habermas)", ''PRAXIS International'' (4/1988), pp. 377-404.</ref> Later thinkers whom he influenced, such as the philosopher [[GyÃ¶rgy LukÃ¡cs]] and the sociologist [[JÃ¼rgen Habermas]], followed with similar arguments of their own.<ref>[[GyÃ¶rgy LukÃ¡cs]]'s ''The Destruction of Reason''; [[JÃ¼rgen Habermas]]'s ''The Philosophical Discourse of Modernity''</ref> However, [[methodological individualism|methodological individualist]] philosophers, such as [[Karl Popper]] and [[Friedrich Hayek]], who reject the reality of and the appeal to [[collectivism|collective]] entities such as [[Social class|class]], in turn criticized Marx and [[Marxism|Marxist]] philosophy as obscurantist.<ref>Wright, E. O., Levine, A., & Sober, E. (1992). ''Reconstructing Marxism: essays on explanation and the theory of history''. London: Verso, 107.</ref>
====Wittgenstein==== [[Ludwig Wittgenstein]]âs obscurantism is illuminated by the criticism of the limits-of-language proposition presented in the [[Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus]] (1921),{{citation needed|November, 2010, the previous citation was another wikipedia article|date=November 2010}} and in abandoning empirical explanation of linguistic description in later works. [[Friedrich Waismann]] accused Wittgenstein of "complete obscurantism" for betraying empirical inquiry;<ref>Shanker, S., & Shanker, V. A. (1986), ''Ludwig Wittgenstein: critical assessments''. London: Croom Helm,50-51.</ref> this criticism then was developed by [[Ernest Gellner]].<ref>''Words and things: An examination of, and an attack on, linguistic philosophy''. London: Routledge & Kegan Paul, 1979, 1959.</ref> In ''Wittgenstein on Freud and Frazer'' (1988), Frank Cioffi discusses âlimits obscurantismâ, âmethod obscurantismâ, and âsensibility obscurantismâ as the varieties of obscurantism found in the philosophy of Ludwig Wittgenstein.<ref>Cioffi, F. (1998), ''Wittgenstein on Freud and Frazer''. Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press, 183ff, chapter 7 on ''Wittgenstein and obscurantism''.</ref>
====Heidegger==== [[Martin Heidegger]], and those influenced by him, such as [[Jacques Derrida]] and [[Emmanuel Levinas]], have been labeled obscurantists by critics from [[Analytic Philosophy]] and the [[Critical theory (Frankfurt School)|Frankfurt School of Critical Theory]]. Of Heidegger, [[Bertrand Russell]] wrote, "his philosophy is extremely obscure. One cannot help suspecting that language is here running riot. An interesting point in his speculations is the insistence that nothingness is something positive. As with much else in Existentialism, this is a psychological observation made to pass for logic."<ref>{{cite book | last = Russell | first = Bertrand | authorlink = Bertrand Russell | title = Wisdom of the West | publisher = Crescent Books | year = 1989 | pages = 303 | isbn = 978-0517690413}}</ref> That is Russell's complete entry on Heidegger, and it expresses the sentiments of many 20th-century [[Analytic Philosophy|Analytic philosophers]] concerning Heidegger.<ref>[http://www.amazon.com/dp/0801485649 Amazon.com: Heidegger: An Introduction: Books: Richard F. H. Polt<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
====Derrida==== {{Unbalanced|date=April 2011}} In their obituaries, âJacques Derrida, Abstruse Theorist, Dies at 74â (10 October 2004) and âObituary of Jacques Derrida, French intellectualâ (21 October 2004), ''[[The New York Times]]'' newspaper<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/2004/10/10/obituaries/10derrida.html?ex=1255147200&en=bc84f1b2c5f092c5&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland Jacques Derrida, Abstruse Theorist, Dies at 74]</ref> and ''[[The Economist]]'' magazine,<ref>[http://www.economist.com/displaystory.cfm?story_id=3308320 Obituary of Jacques Derrida, French intellectual]</ref> described the dead man as a deliberately obscure philosopher.
The [[topology|topologist]] [[RenÃ© Thom]] and the [[analytic philosophy|analytic tradition]] logician [[W. V. Quine]] called [[Jacques Derrida]]âs work âpseudophilosophyâ and âsophistryâ, and were seconded, in the ''New York Review of Books'' article âAn Exchange on Deconstructionâ (February 1984), by [[John Searle]]âs comments on [[Deconstruction]]: â. . . anyone who reads deconstructive texts with an open mind is likely to be struck by the same phenomena that initially surprised me: the low level of philosophical argumentation, the deliberate obscurantism of the prose, the wildly exaggerated claims, and the constant striving to give the appearance of profundity, by making claims that seem paradoxical, but under analysis often turn out to be silly or trivial.â<ref>{{cite journal | last = Mackey | first = Louis H. | title = An Exchange on Deconstruction (Reply by John R. Searle) | journal = New York Review of Books | volume = 31 | issue = 1 | date = February 2, 1984 | url = http://www.nybooks.com/articles/5964 | accessdate = 2007-08-17 }}</ref>
In ''[[Contingency, Irony, and Solidarity]]'' (1989), [[Richard Rorty]] proposed that in ''The Post Card: From Socrates to Freud and Beyond'' (1978), Jacques Derrida purposefully used undefinable words (e.g. [[DiffÃ©rance]]), and used defined words in contexts so diverse that they render the words unintelligible, hence, the reader is unable to establish a context for his literary self. In that way, the philosopher Derrida escapes metaphysical accounts of his work. Since the work ostensibly contains no metaphysics, Derrida has, consequently, escaped metaphysics.<ref name=Rorty/>
Derrida's philosophic work is especially controversial among American and British academics, as when the [[University of Cambridge]] awarded him an honorary doctorate, despite opposition from among the Cambridge philosophy faculty and analytical philosophers worldwide. To wit, in opposing the decision, slated for 16 May 1992, Prof. Barry Smith, ''The Monist'' magazine editor, in ''[[The Times]]'' of London, published ''From Professor Barry Smith and others'', an earnest [http://ontology.buffalo.edu/smith/varia/Derrida_Letter.htm letter of protestation] arguing that:
:âIn the eyes of philosophers, and certainly among those working in leading departments of philosophy throughout the world, M. Derridaâs work does not meet accepted standards of clarity and rigour . . . M. Derridaâs career had its roots in the heady days of the 1960s and his writings continue to reveal their origins in that period. Many of them seem to consist in no small part of elaborate jokes and the puns âlogical phallusiesâ and the like, and M. Derrida seems to us to have come close to making a career out of what we regard as [[translation|translating]] into the academic sphere tricks and gimmicks similar to those of the [[Dada]]ists or of the [[concrete poetry|concrete poets]] . . . Certainly he has shown considerable originality in this respect. But again, we submit, such originality does not lend credence to the idea that he is a suitable candidate for an honorary degree . . . M. Derridaâs voluminous writings in our view stretch the normal forms of [[Scholarly method|academic scholarship]] beyond recognition. Above all â as every reader can very easily establish for himself (and for this purpose any page will do) â his works employ a written style that defies comprehension . . . [thus] Academic status based on what seems to us to be little more than semi-intelligible attacks upon the values of reason, truth, and scholarship is not, we submit, sufficient grounds for the awarding of an honorary degree in a distinguished university.â <ref>Barry Smith et al., "Open letter against Derrida receiving an honorary doctorate from Cambridge University," ''The Times'' [London], 9 May 1992. [http://courses.nus.edu.sg/course/elljwp/againstdsdegree.htm]</ref>
Despite the academicsâ public letter of protestation, signed by Prof. Smith, [[Hugh Mellor]], W. V. Quine, [[David Malet Armstrong|David Armstrong]], [[Ruth Barcan Marcus]], RenÃ© Thom, and twelve others, Cambridge University conferred the honorary doctorate upon him, albeit with a vote of only{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}} 62%.
====Lacan==== [[Jacques Lacan]] was an [[intellectual]] who defended obscurantism, to a degree. To his studentsâ complaint about the deliberate obscurity of his lectures, he replied: "The less you understand, the better you listen."<ref>{{Cite journal | url = http://books.google.com/?id=7Xw4AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA141&lpg=PA141&dq=%22The+less+you+understand,+the+better+you+listen%22#v=onepage&q=%22The%20less%20you%20understand%2C%20the%20better%20you%20listen%22&f=false | title = The ego in Freud's theory and in the technique of psychoanalysis, 1954-1955 | isbn = 9780521318013 | author1 = Lacan | first1 = Jacques | year = 1988}}</ref> In the 1973 seminar ''Encore'', he said that his ''Ãcrits'' (''Writings'') were not to be understood, but would effect a meaning in the reader, like that induced by mystical texts. The obscurity is not in his writing style, but in the repeated allusions to Hegel, derived from [[Alexandre KojÃ¨ve]]âs lectures on Hegel, and similar theoretic divergences.{{Citation needed|date=September 2007}}
====Sokal==== '''Deference to Authority: obscurantism internalized'''
<blockquote>The Displacement of the idea that facts and evidence matter, by the idea that everything boils down to [[Subjectivism|subjective]] interests and perspectives is â second only to American political campaigns â the most prominent and pernicious manifestation of [[anti-intellectualism]] in our time. â [[Larry Laudan]], ''Science and Relativism'' (1990)</blockquote>
The [[Sokal Affair]] (1996) was a publishing [[hoax]] that [[New York University]] [[physics|physicist]] [[Alan Sokal]] perpetrated on the editors and readers of ''[[Social Text]]'', an [[academic journal]] of [[postmodernism|post-modern]] [[cultural studies]] that was not then [[peer review|peer-reviewed]]. In [[1996]], as an experiment testing [[publishing|editorial]] integrity (fact-checking, peer review), Prof. Sokal submitted a [[Pseudoscience|pseudoscientific]] article â proposing that physical reality is a social construct â to learn if ''Social Text'' would âpublish an article liberally salted with nonsense if: (a) it sounded good, and, (b) it flattered the editorsâ ideological preconceptions.â <ref name = Physicist>{{cite web | url = http://www.physics.nyu.edu/faculty/sokal/lingua_franca_v4/lingua_franca_v4.html | title = A Physicist Experiments With Cultural Studies | accessdate= April 3, 2007 | author = Alan D. Sokal | last = Sokal | first = Alan | authorlink = Alan Sokal | work = [[Lingua Franca (magazine)|Lingua Franca]] | year = 1996 | month = May }}</ref>
''Social Text'' published the article, âTransgressing the Boundaries: Towards a Transformative Hermeneutics of Quantum Gravityâ, by Prof. Alan Sokal, in the Spring/Summer 1996 issue, dedicated to the [[Science Wars]], then occurring in US academia, about the conceptual validity of scientific objectivity.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.physics.nyu.edu/~as2/transgress_v2/transgress_v2_singlefile.html | title = Transgressing the Boundaries: Towards a Transformative Hermeneutics of Quantum Gravity | accessdate= 3 April 2007 | author = Alan D. Sokal | last = Sokal | first = Alan | authorlink = Alan Sokal | date = 1994-11-28, revised 1995-05-13, published May 1996 | work = [[Social Text]] #46/47 (spring/summer 1996) | publisher = [[Duke University]] Press | pages = 217â252 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070326153354/http://www.physics.nyu.edu/~as2/transgress_v2/transgress_v2_singlefile.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 26 March 2007}}</ref> Amid intellectual battles about the nature of scientific theory, among [[Scientific realism|scientific realists]] and [[Postmodernism|postmodern critics]], Prof. Sokal submitted his hoax article for publication. The ''raison de guerre'' being that postmodernist critics questioned the [[objectivity (science)|objectivity]] of science, usually via the criticism of scientific method and knowledge, usually in the disciplines of [[cultural studies]], [[cultural anthropology]], [[feminist studies]], [[comparative literature]], [[media studies]], and [[science and technology studies]]. Whereas the scientific realists countered that objective scientific knowledge exists, riposting that postmodernist critics almost knew nothing of the science they criticized. In the event, editorial deference to â[[Appeal to Authority|Academic Authority]]â (the AuthorâProfessor) prompted the editors of ''Social Text'' to not fact-check Prof. Sokalâs manuscript, by submitting it to peer review, by a scientist.
Hence, and elsewhere, on publication day, in the May 1996 edition of the ''[[Lingua Franca (magazine)|Lingua Franca]]'' journal, in the article âA Physicist Experiments With Cultural Studiesâ, Prof. Sokal announced that his transformative hermeneutics article was a [[parody]], submitted âto test the prevailing intellectual standardsâ, concluding that, as an academic publication, ''Social Text'' ignored the requisite [[intellectual rigor]] of verification and âfelt comfortable publishing an article on [[quantum physics]] without bothering to consult anyone knowledgeable in the subject.â <ref name = Physicist /><ref name="LinguaFranca">{{Cite news | last = Sokal| first = Alan | title = A Physicist Experiments With Cultural Studies | pages = 2| newspaper = Lingua Franca| date = May/June 1886| url = http://www.ee.bgu.ac.il/~censor/katz-directory/01-07-17sokal-lingua-franca-experiment.pdf| accessdate =27 January 2010}}</ref> Moreover, as a [[Intellectual|public intellectual]], Prof. Sokal said his hoax was an action protesting against the contemporary tendency towards obscurantism â abstruse, esoteric, and vague writing in the [[social sciences]]:
<blockquote>In short, my concern over the spread of [[subjectivism|subjectivist]] thinking is both [[intellectual]] and [[politics|political]]. Intellectually, the problem with such [[doctrine]]s is that they are false (when not simply meaningless). There is a real world; its properties are not merely social constructions; facts and evidence do matter. What sane person would contend otherwise? And yet, much contemporary academic theorizing consists precisely of attempts to blur these obvious truths â the utter absurdity of it all being concealed through obscure and pretentious language.<ref name = Physicist /></blockquote>
Moreover, independent of the hoax, as a pseudoscientific [[Magnum opus|opus]], the article âTransgressing the Boundaries: Towards a Transformative Hermeneutics of Quantum Gravityâ is described as an exemplar â[[pastiche]] of [[left-wing politics|left-wing]] [[Cant (language)|cant]], fawning references, grandiose quotations, and outright nonsense, centered on the claim that physical reality is merely a social construct.â<ref>{{cite journal | last = Harrell | first = Evans | title = A Report from the Front of the "Science Wars": The controversy over the book ''Higher Superstition,'' by Gross and Levitt and the recent articles by Sokal | journal = Notices of the American Mathematical Society | volume = 43 | issue = 10 | pages = 1132â1136 | month = October | year = 1996 | url = http://www.ams.org/notices/199610/comm-harrell.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2007-09-16 }}</ref> [[Image:Friedrich Hayek portrait.jpg|thumb|right|120px|<center>[[Friedrich August von Hayek]]</center>]]
==Appealing to emotion== The economist [[Friedrich von Hayek]] used the term âobscurantismâ differently, to denote and describe the denial of the truth of scientific theory because of disagreeable [[Morality|moral]] consequences. In the essay âWhy I Am Not a Conservativeâ (1960), he disparages [[conservatism]] for its inability to adapt to changing human realities, or to offer a positive political program. The connotation of his usage of âobscurantismâ is akin to the meaning of the [[appeal to consequences]] fallacy.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}}
